Cold emailing works! I did this in two springs and got responses and was able to intern in a lab the subsequent summers.

Some notes:

- If you have specific profs/labs in mind, send emails to them and follow up in person (if you and they are at Berkeley). Possibly email their grad students too as they might have projects in mind.

- If you don't have specific ones in mind: Send lots of emails to anyone you think you might be interested in working with. E.g. sending emails to  20~30 profs is fine.

- Response rate will be somewhat low. Not sure what year you are in but my freshman spring it was pretty low (e.g. ~10%), but all you need is one yes!

- Timeline: Now works (actually slightly on the later side rn). If profs don't respond within a week I'd suggest pinging them again politely as they may have missed the first one.

What I'd recommend writing in emails:

- Intro about yourself (e.g. year, major, relevant classes) and attach a resume

- Short blurb about what you are interested in or what work of theirs you find interesting.

My email was somewhat short (i.e. 4-5 lines), your could easily be longer if you have more interesting/relevant stuff to write. Hope this helps!
